head.title: Mason's 22 Match 22 By Ewing; Starks Hurt

hedline.hl1: Mason's 22 Match 22 By Ewing; Starks Hurt

block.p: On a night in which the Knicks produced their best point run of the season and held an opponent under 90 points for the 18th time this season, Pat Riley still had a lot about which to fret.

Mainly, the Knicks' coach was concerned about a recurring left shoulder injury to guard John Starks, who went out midway in the fourth quarter of tonight's 96-87 victory over Miami, grimacing and holding his shoulder.
On a night in which the Knicks produced their best point run of the season and held an opponent under 90 points for the 18th time this season, Pat Riley still had a lot about which to fret.

Mainly, the Knicks' coach was concerned about a recurring left shoulder injury to guard John Starks, who went out midway in the fourth quarter of tonight's 96-87 victory over Miami, grimacing and holding his shoulder.
Starks, who was only 2 of 10 in field-goal shooting, had reached in guarding Glen Rice and immediately grabbed the shoulder when Rice collided with him.
Officially, he has a subluxation, a partly dislocated shoulder. Starks, who underwent X-rays, said he had injured the shoulder worse than in games against Utah and Houston.
"It felt like a lot of ligaments got torn in there," he said somberly. "I hope I'm wrong. We'll know more tomorrow."
If Starks is unable to play in a rematch with the Heat Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Hubert Davis figures to get more playing time.
"I'm not even thinking about that," said Davis, who hit a key 3-pointer near the third quarter's end tonight en route to 10 points for the game. "I'll just have to go out there and see what happens."
New York got strong performances from Patrick Ewing and Anthony Mason, who had 22 points each, along with Derek Harper, 20.
"We just have trouble conjuring up the energy we need to start games," Riley said. "Right now we're stuck in mud. We were lethargic at the beginning."

Things changed when Mason, who also had a team-high 14 rebounds, entered midway through the first quarter. Even though New York wound up on the short end of a 28-22 first-quarter score, Mason's influence was apparent.
"He brings an awful lot of intensity to the game," Riley said of his No. 1 reserve. "Seems like tonight he had as much intensity as the other four guys combined."

With Ewing getting two fouls in the game's first 3:51, it was left to Harper to keep the Knicks in the game early. He scored 11 points in the quarter and nearly had more -- his 40-footer hit off the front rim at the buzzer.

Still, Miami led by 28-22, largely on the strength of Billy Owens's 9 points and Rice's 7. A point was taken away from Miami after the end of the quarter, when Owens's long jumper with 2.7 seconds left was deemed worth 2 points, not 3.

Herb Williams, Ewing's replacement, celebrated his 37th birthday today, but definitely not on the court. He wound up with 1 point, and particularly struggled in the opening quarter, missing three shots and looking tentative.

Ewing re-entered the game to start the second quarter and New York promptly produced its hottest streak of the season. Within a span of 3:29, the Knicks had the lead again, at 32-30, and they weren't through. Before their season-high 17-point run was over, they had stretched their margin to 44-30.
"Defense was the key," Riley said. "And quickness. They had some misses and a few of our guys got hot."
Ewing was the obvious catalyst, scoring 13 points, including his team's first 3, and getting 7 rebounds.
Mason also had a distinguished quarter. His twisting moves around the basket produced 6 points, and he added 3 rebounds, along with a 60-foot pass that led to an easy Ewing layup.
Harper finished off the 28-11 quarter with a jump shot just four-tenths of a second before halftime, putting the Knicks on top, 50-39.
New York's longest streak of unanswered points before tonight was 14, against New Jersey Dec. 27 and against Milwaukee Jan. 13.
Curiously two of Miami's three 3 biggest offensive weapons, Owens and Kevin Willis, each sat out at least half of the second quarter as the Heat went scoreless for 4:55.
But Coach Alvin Gentry, who replaced Kevin Loughery just two days ago, has acknowledged that he intends to do some experimenting.

In the third quarter, Miami drew within 3 points of the Knicks once and within 4 on two occasions, the last time at 68-64, when Rice, who had 33 points, was deadly with a 3. Riley called a timeout and Miami Arena rocked with excitement.
But the little-used Davis then quieted the home-towners with a straight-away 3-pointer at the 38-second mark.
That allowed New York to enter the final quarter ahead, 71-64. The Knicks' lead never got below 6 points thereafter, but the game turned rough.
Anthony Bonner was ejected with 7:11 left because of a flagrant foul on Miami's Matt Geiger as the 7-footer drove for a layup. His legs cut out from under him, Geiger hit the floor with a loud thud.
Several minutes earlier, Geiger and Mason had a heated exchange, after Mason knocked him down on a drive.

With 3:43 left, Ewing was whistled for a double technical foul along with Willis for their bumping and threatening talk. And inside the final minute, Rice and Harper drew double technicals for their uncomplimentary rejoinders.
In the end, though, the Knicks got what they wanted and now they are looking at five home games in a row. PRO BASKETBALL
